Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: A discovery and prediction platform for microbial data
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is to develop a software platform to automate the integration and analysis of large sets of biological data. This project will help lift the barrier that exists in data analysis and experimental planning by providing the latest computational advances in machine learning and bioinformatics. The goal is to create a cohesive data universe for microbial organisms, where each new dataset can be easily integrated, compared, and ultimately leveraged to increase collective knowledge. Such homogenized sets of structured biological data are ideal training sets for predictive models that can accelerate discovery times by transforming the traditional "shot-in-the dark" way of experimentation to guided, well-connected hypotheses, generated from the complete set of data at hand.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to build a software tool for automated hypothesis generation based on biological datasets. First, it will support the design of a novel multi-omics engine that will allow the creation of a cohesive compendium of the omics and interaction universe for microbial organisms. Second, it will lead to the development of predictive modeling tools that will interrogate and transform this data compendium into a semantic web of actionable predictions. Third, it will support the evaluation of novel active learning methodologies for omics data. This project will lead to a software architecture that can put all of these tools under one platform to empower commercial clients as well as the academic community. Once completed, the product will offer an automated, end-to-end environment and decision support engine fueled by the collective knowledge. In that sense, it will be a personalized experience on an ecosystem of pre- and post-processing services for biological data.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project award was to develop an end-to-end, multi-omics software platform that automates the integration and analysis of omics data, a platform capable of offering AI-driven recommendations on optimally navigating the experimental space. As part of the project, we carried out a bootcamp, commercialization activities and Alpha and Beta prototype testing of the web-based, zero-config, transcriptomics analysis platform. Technical milestones we reached include designing a scalable and modular architecture of multi-omics data analysis, designing a prototype of the data and metadata types supported, developing analytics and bioinformatics pipelines, and collecting market insights as to the organisms, features, and data the tool should support to be truly valuable to scientists and researchers. The prototype supports transcriptomics data analysis through the use of the bowtie2 aligner followed by the htseq-count for gene counting pipeline. This pipeline is available for three major organisms of E. coli, A. thaliana, and H. sapiens. The tool also supports the use of single-end and paired-end libraries and can run analytics such as hierarchical clustering, PCA (principal component analysis), t-SNE, DEG (differential expression analysis), and GO (gene ontology) analysis.

 

Both market research and prototype testing revealed that the needs of potential users did not align with our prioritization of an AI-driven, optimal experiment design module. Rather, prospects are interested in having access to efficient data management and bioinformaticians for technical support. This hypothesis was validated during customer interviews, market research and testing. The greatest, unexpected outcome of Phase I is that we crystallized the scope and core functionality of the platform; namely to provide an omics data universe for major human diseases. The new, niche scope of the tool will be built on top of its fundamental features; modularity, scalability, user-friendliness, and ease of use.

 


Last Modified: 05/24/2019
Modified by: Minseung Kim
